Translator: Joseph Geni
Reviewer: Morton Bast

16.53.text: Before March, 2011, I was a photographic retoucher

25.58.text: We hide in dark, windowless rooms,

29.97.text: We make skinny models skinnier, perfect skin more perfect,

36.22.text: and we get criticized in the press all the time,

40.27.text: but some of us are actually talented artists

45.85.text: and a real appreciation for images and photography.

49.75.text: On March 11, 2011, I watched from home, as the rest

54.92.text: of the world did, as the tragic events unfolded in Japan.

58.75.text: Soon after, an organization I volunteer with,

60.92.text: All Hands Volunteers, were on the ground, within days,

64.77.text: working as part of the response efforts.

67.60.text: I, along with hundreds of other volunteers,

69.89.text: knew we couldn't just sit at home,

71.56.text: so I decided to join them for three weeks.

75.28.text: On May the 13th, I made my way to the town of Ōfunato.

78.93.text: It's a small fishing town in Iwate Prefecture,

85.01.text: one of the first that was hit by the wave.

87.82.text: The waters here have been recorded at reaching

93.33.text: and traveled over two miles inland.

95.04.text: As you can imagine, the town had been devastated.

98.58.text: We pulled debris from canals and ditches.

101.11.text: We cleaned schools. We de-mudded and gutted homes

107.04.text: We cleared tons and tons of stinking, rotting fish carcasses

111.50.text: from the local fish processing plant.

113.71.text: We got dirty, and we loved it.

117.12.text: For weeks, all the volunteers and locals alike

122.48.text: They'd been finding photos and photo albums

128.06.text: And everyone was doing the same.

129.28.text: They were collecting them up, and handing them in to

131.94.text: various places around the different towns for safekeeping.

135.11.text: Now, it wasn't until this point that I realized

138.23.text: that these photos were such a huge part

140.66.text: of the personal loss these people had felt.

143.66.text: As they had run from the wave, and for their lives,

148.97.text: everything had to be left behind.

151.80.text: At the end of my first week there, I found myself

154.08.text: helping out in an evacuation center in the town.

157.28.text: I was helping clean the onsen, the communal onsen,

162.92.text: This happened to also be a place in the town where

165.35.text: the evacuation center was collecting the photos.

168.36.text: This is where people were handing them in,

170.28.text: and I was honored that day that they actually trusted me

172.79.text: to help them start hand-cleaning them.

175.44.text: Now, it was emotional and it was inspiring,

178.48.text: and I've always heard about thinking outside the box,

182.24.text: but it wasn't until I had actually gotten outside of my box

188.08.text: As I looked through the photos, there were some

190.13.text: were over a hundred years old,

191.90.text: some still in the envelope from the processing lab,

195.48.text: I couldn't help but think as a retoucher

197.37.text: that I could fix that tear and mend that scratch,

200.20.text: and I knew hundreds of people who could do the same.

204.24.text: So that evening, I just reached out on Facebook

206.62.text: and asked a few of them, and by morning

208.82.text: the response had been so overwhelming and so positive,

212.30.text: I knew we had to give it a go.

219.81.text: Not terribly damaged, but where the water had caused

224.41.text: that discoloration on the girl's face

226.60.text: had to be repaired with such accuracy and delicacy.

230.20.text: Otherwise, that little girl isn't going to look

232.50.text: like that little girl anymore, and surely that's as tragic

245.07.text: Over time, more photos came in, thankfully,

251.76.text: and so I reached out again on Facebook and LinkedIn,

254.70.text: and within five days, 80 people wanted to help

259.75.text: Within two weeks, I had 150 people

263.99.text: Within Japan, by July, we'd branched out

266.36.text: to the neighboring town of Rikuzentakata,

268.98.text: further north to a town called Yamada.

271.37.text: Once a week, we would set up our scanning equipment

274.64.text: in the temporary photo libraries that had been set up,

277.15.text: where people were reclaiming their photos.

279.52.text: The older ladies sometimes hadn't seen a scanner before,

283.35.text: but within 10 minutes of them finding their lost photo,

287.22.text: they could give it to us, have it scanned,

289.13.text: uploaded to a cloud server, it would be downloaded

293.78.text: somewhere on the other side of the globe,

298.25.text: The time it took, however, to get it back

303.43.text: and it depended obviously on the damage involved.

306.02.text: It could take an hour. It could take weeks.

309.86.text: The kimono in this shot pretty much had to be hand-drawn,

313.97.text: or pieced together, picking out the remaining parts of color

317.68.text: and detail that the water hadn't damaged.

322.85.text: Now, all these photos had been damaged by water,

325.47.text: submerged in salt water, covered in bacteria,

328.80.text: in sewage, sometimes even in oil, all of which over time

332.24.text: is going to continue to damage them,

334.19.text: so hand-cleaning them was a huge part of the project.

337.30.text: We couldn't retouch the photo unless it was cleaned,

343.29.text: Now, we were lucky with our hand-cleaning.

345.74.text: We had an amazing local woman who guided us.

348.98.text: It's very easy to do more damage to those damaged photos.

353.17.text: As my team leader Wynne once said,

354.96.text: it's like doing a tattoo on someone.

356.90.text: You don't get a chance to mess it up.

360.43.text: The lady who brought us these photos was lucky,

363.42.text: as far as the photos go.

365.65.text: She had started hand-cleaning them herself and stopped

368.03.text: when she realized she was doing more damage.

372.70.text: Areas like her husband and her face, which otherwise

375.79.text: would have been completely impossible to fix,

377.90.text: we could just put them together in one good photo,

383.21.text: When she collected the photos from us,

385.88.text: she shared a bit of her story with us.

388.25.text: Her photos were found by her husband's colleagues

391.21.text: at a local fire department in the debris

393.20.text: a long way from where the home had once stood,

398.49.text: The day of the tsunami, he'd actually been in charge

400.77.text: of making sure the tsunami gates were closed.

403.30.text: He had to go towards the water as the sirens sounded.

406.42.text: Her two little boys, not so little anymore, but her two boys

409.87.text: were both at school, separate schools.

412.06.text: One of them got caught up in the water.

414.62.text: It took her a week to find them all again

416.57.text: and find out that they had all survived.

418.97.text: The day I gave her the photos also happened to be

425.84.text: For her, despite all of this, those photos

429.51.text: were the perfect gift back to him,

432.23.text: something he could look at again, something he remembered from before

435.33.text: that wasn't still scarred from that day in March

439.59.text: when absolutely everything else in his life had changed

448.41.text: 1,100 volunteers had passed through All Hands,

451.56.text: hundreds of whom had helped us hand-clean

462.75.text: a large majority of which did actually find their home again,

468.74.text: Over five hundred volunteers around the globe

471.91.text: helped us get 90 families hundreds of photographs back,

478.82.text: During this time, we hadn't really spent more than

481.27.text: about a thousand dollars in equipment and materials,

484.12.text: most of which was printer inks.

490.34.text: A photo is a reminder of someone or something,

492.90.text: a place, a relationship, a loved one.

495.76.text: They're our memory-keepers and our histories,

498.27.text: the last thing we would grab

500.98.text: and the first thing you'd go back to look for.

503.49.text: That's all this project was about,

505.60.text: about restoring those little bits of humanity,

511.14.text: When a photo like this can be returned to someone like this,

518.92.text: in the lives of the person receiving it.

521.70.text: The project's also made a big difference in the lives of the retouchers.

525.50.text: For some of them, it's given them a connection

528.57.text: to something bigger, giving something back,

532.99.text: other than skinny models and perfect skin.

536.41.text: I would like to conclude by reading an email

539.02.text: I got from one of them, Cindy,

541.45.text: the day I finally got back from Japan after six months.

546.05.text: "As I worked, I couldn't help but think about the individuals

549.81.text: and the stories represented in the images.

552.95.text: One in particular, a photo of women of all ages,

556.44.text: from grandmother to little girl, gathered around a baby,

560.82.text: struck a chord, because a similar photo from my family,

566.79.text: and newborn daughter, hangs on our wall.

570.20.text: Across the globe, throughout the ages,

573.35.text: our basic needs are just the same, aren't they?"
